name: Mercury
description: Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun and the smallest one in our solar system. Despite being nearest to the Sun, it's not the hottest—that title goes to Venus. Mercury has no atmosphere to retain heat, so it experiences extreme temperature fluctuations, from scorching 430°C during the day to -180°C at night. Its surface is heavily cratered, resembling Earth’s moon, and it's thought to have a large metallic core which generates a weak magnetic field. Due to its slow rotation and fast orbit, a day on Mercury (sunrise to sunrise) lasts 176 Earth days.

name: Venus
description: Venus, often referred to as Earth's twin because of its similar size and composition, is a hellish world with a thick, toxic atmosphere composed mainly of carbon dioxide. Its surface pressure is about 92 times that of Earth’s, equivalent to being 900 meters underwater. The planet is perpetually shrouded in thick sulfuric acid clouds, trapping heat and creating a runaway greenhouse effect, making Venus the hottest planet in our solar system with surface temperatures over 460°C. Interestingly, Venus rotates in the opposite direction to most planets and very slowly—a day on Venus is longer than its year.

name: Earth
description: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only known celestial body to support life. It has a unique atmosphere rich in nitrogen and oxygen, a magnetic field that shields it from harmful solar radiation, and abundant liquid water covering about 71% of its surface. Earth’s biosphere supports millions of species, including humans. Tectonic activity, weather systems, and a dynamic climate make it an ever-changing world. Its natural satellite, the Moon, influences tides and helps stabilize Earth's rotation.

name: Mars
description: Mars, often called the Red Planet due to its iron oxide-rich soil, is a cold desert world with the largest volcano (Olympus Mons) and deepest canyon (Valles Marineris) in the solar system. Scientists believe that Mars once had liquid water, and possibly life. Today, water exists mostly as ice. The planet experiences huge dust storms and seasonal weather patterns. It has two small moons, Phobos and Deimos, and continues to be a prime target for exploration and potential colonization.

name: Jupiter
description: Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system, a massive gas giant primarily composed of hydrogen and helium. It has at least 92 known moons, including the four largest: Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto. Jupiter is known for its powerful storms, most famously the Great Red Spot—a giant storm that’s been raging for centuries. It has a faint ring system and emits more heat than it receives from the Sun due to internal processes. Jupiter's immense gravity shapes the orbits of many asteroids and comets.

name: Saturn
description: Saturn is renowned for its spectacular ring system, composed of countless icy particles ranging in size from grains of sand to mountains. It's a gas giant like Jupiter, with a thick atmosphere mostly made of hydrogen and helium. Saturn has at least 83 moons, with Titan being the largest and of particular interest due to its dense atmosphere and surface lakes of liquid methane. Despite its size, Saturn is the least dense planet in the solar system—it would float in water if there were a bathtub big enough.

name: Uranus
description: Uranus is an ice giant with a pale blue color caused by methane in its atmosphere. It has a unique rotation—tilted more than 90°, it essentially rolls around the Sun on its side. This extreme axial tilt results in unusual seasons that last over 20 years. Uranus has faint rings, a cold and windy atmosphere, and 27 known moons. It is one of the coldest planets in the solar system, with temperatures dropping below -220°C.

name: Neptune
description: Neptune is the farthest known planet from the Sun and another ice giant. It has a deep blue appearance and the fastest winds in the solar system, reaching up to 2,100 km/h. Like Uranus, it has a thick atmosphere of hydrogen, helium, and methane. Neptune has 14 known moons, with Triton being the largest and geologically active. It also has faint, dusty rings and a dynamic atmosphere with frequent storms and cloud activity.
